channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Sustainable eating habits that can help the environment without taking over your life
item.description: What we eat plays a role in the health of our environment. Here are some things to consider when trying to make doable changes to improve your impact without breaking the bank.
item.content:encoded:
What we eat plays a role in the health of our environment. Here are some things to consider when trying to make doable changes to improve your impact without breaking the bank.

(Image credit: Rob Kim)
item.dc:creator: The NPR Network

item.title: Afghan women sing to protest a law that orders them to keep quiet
item.description: A new morality law is full of restrictions. No neckties for men. Photos cannot be reproduced. The harshest rules are for women — who are singing out on social media to protest the ban on singing.
item.content:encoded:
A new morality law is full of restrictions. No neckties for men. Photos cannot be reproduced. The harshest rules are for women — who are singing out on social media to protest the ban on singing.

(Image credit: Wakil Koshar/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Diaa Hadid

item.title: A rare look inside war-torn Sudan. And, the data behind grocery inflation.
item.description: NPR gets a rare look inside war-torn Sudan, where millions are displaced and struggling for survival. And, we examine new data on why grocery prices remain high.
item.content:encoded:
NPR gets a rare look inside war-torn Sudan, where millions are displaced and struggling for survival. And, we examine new data on why grocery prices remain high.

(Image credit: Luke Dray @lukedrayphoto)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Whatever happened to ... the global effort to wipe out cervical cancer with a vaccine?
item.description: Now that the World Health Organization has endorsed a one-dose vaccine, global health groups are amping up their effort to inoculate the world's girls. How are they doing?
item.content:encoded:
Now that the World Health Organization has endorsed a one-dose vaccine, global health groups are amping up their effort to inoculate the world's girls. How are they doing?

(Image credit: Zhao Song / CFOTO/Future Publishing via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Fran Kritz

item.title: SpaceX Polaris Dawn astronauts conduct the first-ever private spacewalk
item.description: An internet entrepreneur and a SpaceX engineer have become the first private astronauts to walk in space.
item.content:encoded:
An internet entrepreneur and a SpaceX engineer have become the first private astronauts to walk in space.

(Image credit: SpaceX broadcast)
item.dc:creator: Geoff Brumfiel

item.title: Schools are putting vape detectors in bathrooms -- paid for by Juul
item.description: Some districts are using money from a $1.7 billion legal settlement against e-cigarette manufacturer Juul Labs to pay for the high-tech devices. But there are critics and also privacy concerns.
item.content:encoded:
Some districts are using money from a $1.7 billion legal settlement against e-cigarette manufacturer Juul Labs to pay for the high-tech devices. But there are critics and also privacy concerns.

(Image credit: whitebalance.oatt)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: These small Black-owned farms are growing crops with the climate in mind
item.description: Across the Gulf South, small Black-owned farms are finding ways to use climate-friendly practices to grow crops while also addressing long-standing injustices.
item.content:encoded:
Across the Gulf South, small Black-owned farms are finding ways to use climate-friendly practices to grow crops while also addressing long-standing injustices.

(Image credit: Leslie Gamboni)
item.dc:creator: Danny McArthur

item.title: Francine weakens as it moves inland after winds cause widespread blackouts
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of power outages were reported in Louisiana and Mississippi early Thursday as residents in the region braced for possible flooding as Tropical Storm Francine moved inland.
item.content:encoded:
Hundreds of thousands of power outages were reported in Louisiana and Mississippi early Thursday as residents in the region braced for possible flooding as Tropical Storm Francine moved inland.

(Image credit: Brandon Bell)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: What does a busy president want to eat? This White House chef has the answer
item.description: You know that old line, "Tell me what you eat and I'll tell you who you are"? If that's true, then Cristeta Comerford knows the last five presidents of the United States better than almost anyone.
item.content:encoded:
You know that old line, "Tell me what you eat and I'll tell you who you are"? If that's true, then Cristeta Comerford knows the last five presidents of the United States better than almost anyone.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: Protections for minority voters are at the center of a Florida redistricting case
item.description: Voting rights groups challenging the state congressional map want the Florida Supreme Court to reinstate a district that gave Black voters in one region the chance to elect their preferred candidate.
item.content:encoded:
Voting rights groups challenging the state congressional map want the Florida Supreme Court to reinstate a district that gave Black voters in one region the chance to elect their preferred candidate.

(Image credit: Brendan Farrington)
item.dc:creator: Valerie Crowder
